user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl:
```c
void OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_unlock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /* Restore previous cancellability state */
        pthread_setcancelstate(OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState, NULL);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pthread_mutex_unlock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The pthread_mutex_unlock API has prototype int pthread_mutex_unlock(pthread_mutex_t *mutex) and modifies the mutex object, so a pointer to non-const is required. Passing &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex is appropriate; the pointer cannot be const-qualified here because the function changes the mutex state.
